name: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
description: The most severe form of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, caused by mutations in COL3A1 affecting type III collagen. Characterized by arterial rupture, bowel perforation, and uterine rupture without significant preceding dilation. Surgery carries extremely high risk.

pathophysiology.type_iii_collagen: Major component of blood vessel walls, intestines, uterus
pathophysiology.mechanism: Defective or reduced type III collagen production
pathophysiology.result: Tissue fragility with spontaneous rupture WITHOUT preceding dilation
pathophysiology.key_difference: Vessels rupture at NORMAL diameters (unlike Marfan/LDS)

minor_criteria: Characteristic facies (thin lips, small chin, thin nose, hollow eyes)

vascular_complications.age_of_event: Mean age 23-25 years for first major event

diagnosis.clinical_suspicion: Unexplained arterial rupture in young patient
diagnosis.biochemical: Collagen analysis of fibroblast culture (rarely done now)

villefranche_criteria.diagnosis: 2+ major OR 1 major + minor features + family history

avoid_surgery_when_possible.rationale: Tissue fragility makes surgery extremely high risk

conservative_management.arterial_hemorrhage: Endovascular preferred over open when possible

medical.celiprolol: Beta-blocker shown to reduce vascular events in trial

clinical_pearls: Vessels RUPTURE without DILATING first - unlike Marfan/LDS
Surgery is LAST RESORT due to tissue fragility
Thin translucent skin with visible veins = think vEDS
learning_objectives: Explain why vEDS patients rupture vessels at normal diameters
Describe the surgical risks in vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
Outline management strategies that minimize surgical intervention
